awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Human-Centric Knowledge Discovery and Decision Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans are both producers and consumers of Big Data. Modeling the role of humans in the process of mining Big Data is thus critical for unleashing the vast potential of mined knowledge in various important domains such as health, education, security, and scientific discovery. The objective of this research is to build a human-centric learning framework, which harnesses the power of human-generated Big Data with computational models. This research project also focuses on incorporating conducted research activities into teaching materials for student training and education in the areas of information retrieval and data mining. In addition, specialized training in data analytics methods and applications is provided to enhance the education of Big Data related techniques for non-STEM and community college students.

This project comprises four synergistic research thrusts. First, joint text and behavior analysis. To exploit as many types of human-generated data as possible and capture the dependencies among them, this project develops a set of novel probabilistic generative models to perform integrative analysis of text and behavior data. Second, task-based online decision optimization. Traditional static, ad-hoc and passive machine-human interactions are inadequate to optimize humans' dynamic decision making processes. To address this limitation, users' longitudinal information seeking activities are organized into tasks, where new online learning algorithms are applied to proactively infer users' intents and adapt the systems for long-term utility optimization. Third, explainable personalization. Existing personalized systems are black boxes to their users. Users typically have little control over how their information is used to personalize systems. To help ordinary users be aware of how the system's behavior is customized and increase their trust in such systems, statistical learning algorithms are built to generate both system-oriented and user-oriented explanations. Fourth, system implementation and prototyping. User studies are conducted in a prototype system integrated with all the algorithms developed in this project to evaluate the deployed algorithms. Evaluation and feedback from real users are circulated back to refine the assumptions and design of the developed algorithms. Expected results of the project include: 1) open source tools and web services that will provide joint analysis of human-generated text data and behavior data in various applications, such as search logs, forum discussions, and opinionated reviews; and 2) annotated corpora and new evaluation metrics that will enable researchers to conduct follow-up research in related domains.

por.por_cntn:
Humans are both producers and consumers of Big Data. Modeling the role of humans in the process of mining Big Data is thus critical for unleashing the vast potential of mined knowledge in various important domains such as healthcare, education, finance, and scientific discovery. The specific aim of this research is to build a human-centric learning framework, which harnesses the power of human-generated Big Data with computational models. This research project also focuses on incorporating the developed research activities into teaching materials for student training and education in the areas of information retrieval and data mining. 


This project comprises four synergistic research thrusts, and each thrust produced considerable outcomes to the research community, including new algorithmic solutions and datasets. First, joint text and behavior analysis. We took a holistic view of user-generated data through the lens of social psychology and cognitive behavioral theories, and explicitly model the dependency among users across different data modalities. The value of our research in this direction has been validated in various real-world applications. For example, we modeled students' learning behaviors in online education platforms to personalize their learning experience; and we quantified patients' behavior trait in an online training platform developed at UVA for anxiety prevention to obtain more accurate attrition predictions in its participants. 

Second, task-based online decision optimization. We developed solutions for an array of important online decision optimization problems, where particular emphasis has been given to both theoretical guarantees and practical effectiveness. For example, by explicitly modeling users? click behaviors in the problem of online learning to rank, we proved considerable variance reduction is achievable for regret minimization. This work was awarded the Best Paper Award at SIGIR?2019. In addition to the algorithms? promising theoretical results, our solutions also achieved impressive performance in several industry deployments, including Yahoo news recommendation and Snapchat lens recommendation.


Third, explainable personalization. To inform users about personalized information filtering in a recommender system, we married two companion learning tasks, user intent modeling for recommendation and opinionated content modeling for explanation. Our algorithms predict not only a user's preference over a list of items, but also how the user would appreciate the item to generate natural language explanations. Special attention was given to the fidelity of the generated explanations and its informativeness in helping users compare the recommendations. Our effort in explainablity offers transparency of customized results that allows users to make more informed and accurate decisions about which results to utilize and thus increases user trust.


Fourth, system implementation and prototyping. We developed two prototype systems to deploy and evaluate our developed user behavior models and interactive decision optimization algorithms. One system provides personalized retrieval of opinionated text content in a large collection of review data, and another system is built on a Chrome extension to perform real-time Google search result reranking. Both systems are open-sourced to facilitate the community to take advantage of them for follow-up system development and evaluation. 


The latest research achievement has been constantly incorporated into the PI?s undergraduate-level Information Retrieval class and graduate-level Text Mining class. And all the course materials, including lecture slides and homework assignments, are made available to public. The PI has been invited to various academic and industry seminars to talk about the research outcomes produced in this project.
